title: North Carolina House GOP Overrides Budget Veto With Few Democrats Present
text:
Confusion erupted in North Carolina when Republican lawmakers voted to override the Democratic governor’s veto of the state budget with only about half of the members of the state’s House of Representatives present.

The House early Wednesday overrode Gov. Roy Cooper ’s veto in a 55-9 vote, along party lines. There are 65 Republicans in the House and 55 Democrats.

In North Carolina, a three-fifths majority of members present is required to pass an override vote, meaning the proposal Wednesday may not have passed with a party-line vote of the House with all members present.

Democratic Party leaders said only nine Democrats were in attendance because they were told no votes would be called at the early-morning session. Republican leaders have said there was no such public announcement.

Democrats objected when Rep. Jason Saine, a Republican, made a motion to reconsider the state budget vetoed earlier this summer by the governor, according to an audio recording of the session. Within seconds, Rep. Deb Butler, a Democrat, told Republican House Speaker Tim Moore that Democrats had understood no votes would be held.

“This is a travesty of the process, and you know it,” Ms. Butler said.

In a news conference Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Moore said he took the opportunity to override the veto, as he said he had promised to do. “There was never any notice that went out saying there would not be recorded votes,” he said.

“While some want to turn around and fuss and argue about procedure, look,” he added, “if they didn’t want it to pass, all they had to do was show up for work.”

Joseph Kyzer, a spokesman for Mr. Moore, said there wasn’t any coordination among Republicans to vote on the budget without the majority of Democrats present.

House Minority Leader Darren Jackson, a Democrat, motioned for a re-call of the vote when the House convened Wednesday afternoon. The motion failed, 54-61

“I have never seen anything like this in my 30-plus years in state government. Never,” Mr. Cooper said in a news conference Wednesday. “This is a true assault on our democracy, there is no question about it.”

Mr. Cooper vetoed the state’s budget in June, saying it placed a priority on “the wrong things,” such as corporate tax cuts.

The chaos in the state legislature comes just hours after the heavily watched victory of Republican Dan Bishop in a special election in the state’s Ninth Congressional District. (

North Carolina has a history of strong partisanship in the state legislature. Earlier this month, a panel of judges struck down North Carolina’s legislative districts, ruling that Republicans had improperly gerrymandered state voting lines with “surgical precision” to ensure the GOP’s control of the state legislature. In 2016, Republican lawmakers passed legislation restricting the powers of the incoming Democratic governor.

The confusion among lawmakers continued into the afternoon Wednesday as they attempted to piece it all together and different interpretations emerged.

Democratic Rep. Jackson, the House Minority Leader, said Rep. David Lewis, a Republican and chair of the rules committee, told him Tuesday afternoon that no votes would take place at the 8:30 a.m. House session Wednesday. Mr. Jackson said he notified Democrats over email twice Tuesday evening about the schedule, he said.

Mr. Jackson said he was told any votes would start at 1 p.m. Mr. Lewis said in a news conference Wednesday afternoon he never said or suggested votes would start after 1 p.m.

“I do not believe you want to legislate by ambush,” Mr. Jackson said to his Republican colleagues in a session Wednesday afternoon.

Mr. Lewis said it appeared Mr. Jackson “misconstrued” their conversation. “I never said to any member there would be no recorded votes,” Mr. Lewis said.

“I sincerely apologize to Rep. Jackson and all of the members of this House for this genuine, honest disagreement about who said what to whom,” Mr. Lewis said when the House convened Wednesday afternoon.

Democratic leaders in the state Senate have said they will defend the governor’s veto, but the chamber has 29 Republicans and 21 Democrats.

Write to Jennifer Calfas at Jennifer.Calfas@wsj.com
description: Confusion erupted in North Carolina when Republican lawmakers voted to override the Democratic governor’s veto of the state budget with only about half of the members of the state’s House of Representatives present.
